overview: Titus is pastoral instruction for organizing churches on the island of Crete. It emphasizes appointing godly leaders and living in a way that adorns the gospel in a morally corrupt culture.

verses.text: For the grace of God has appeared, bringing salvation for all people, training us to renounce ungodliness and worldly passions, and to live self-controlled, upright, and godly lives in the present age.
He saved us, not because of works done by us in righteousness, but according to his own mercy, by the washing of regeneration and renewal of the Holy Spirit.

passages.title: Grace That Trains
passages.summary: God's saving grace doesn't just forgive—it trains us to live godly lives while we await Christ's return.

passages.title: Good Works
passages.summary: Saved by mercy, not works, believers are now 'zealous for good works'—grace produces, not earns, godliness.

facts.text: Cretans had a reputation for dishonesty—Paul even quotes a Cretan prophet who called them 'liars' (1:12).
Titus is not mentioned in Acts but was Paul's trusted troubleshooter for difficult situations.
'Good works' appears six times in this short letter, emphasizing visible evidence of genuine faith.

figures.name: Paul
figures.description: The apostle giving practical instruction for establishing healthy churches in a challenging culture.

figures.name: Titus
figures.description: Paul's trusted partner, a Gentile convert who handled difficult assignments like organizing Cretan churches.

videos.title: Titus Overview
videos.description: The Bible Project explores how grace trains for godly living.
